text: quick ques: I have a local sledgehammer tarball (from s3) which I want to deploy to another drp-instance (due to version upgrade).
so I copy the tarball to dest instance.
get the bootenv for 'sledgehammer'
update the isoUrl param to point to local disk path for the tarball
and do bootenvs update sledgehammer - < updatedbootenv.list
I get "Error: PATCH: discovery"
no logs on the server side as well
had run the drp server with trace log-level
am I doing it correctly ?
thanks
Login to the portal and update the content package for the community.
Then from the cli run the uploadiso command from the QuickStart.  The community video has Shane talking about this some yesterday  <@U9DAYGSRL>
Using the default DRP-provided preseed partitioning map, getting a failure as so:
(Had wiped the target disk beforehand with `dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/sda bs=1024M` )
<@U416T0AAX> uploaded a file: <https://rackn.slack.com/files/U416T0AAX/F9H62F078/image_uploaded_from_ios.jpg|Preseed partition fail>

Here is the partitioning recipe that is being used:
```
#Partitioning Scheme
d-i partman-auto/disk string /dev/sda
d-i grub-installer/choose_bootdev select /dev/sda
d-i grub-installer/bootdev string /dev/sda
d-i partman-auto/method string lvm
d-i partman-auto-lvm/guided_size string max
d-i partman-auto-lvm/new_vg_name string testnode02
d-i partman-auto/choose_recipe select custom_lvm
d-i partman-auto/expert_recipe string \
    custom_lvm::  \
      500 50 1024 free $iflabel{ gpt } $reusemethod{ } method{ efi } format{ } . \
      128 50 256  ext2 $defaultignore{ } method{ format } format{ } use_filesystem{ } filesystem{ ext2 } mountpoint{ /boot } . \
      10240 20 10240 ext4 $lvmok{ } mountpoint{ / } lv_name{ root } in_vg{ testnode02 } method{ format } format{ } use_filesystem{ } filesystem{ ext4 } . \
      50% 20 100% linux-swap $lvmok{ } lv_name{ swap } in_vg{ testnode02 } method{ swap } format{ } .
d-i grub-installer/only_debian boolean true

d-i partman/confirm_write_new_label boolean true
d-i partman/choose_partition select finish
d-i partman/confirm boolean true
d-i partman/confirm_nooverwrite boolean true
```
Is that the default scheme file as well?
I believe so, but let me dbl-check...
So, yes
